title: FirstFT: Federal Reserve could start to limit stimulus as soon as this year, says Daly
text:
The Federal Reserve could start “dialling back” its pandemic levels of monetary support for the US economy by the end of the year given the strength of the economic rebound, according to a top official at the US central bank.

In an interview with the Financial Times, Mary Daly, president of the San Francisco Fed, expressed confidence that the robust recovery in household and business activity would continue to gather momentum as more people returned to work and consumer spending remained buoyant, setting the stage for a policy pivot in the coming months.

“I remain very optimistic and positive about the [autumn] and ongoing improvements in the key variables we care about,” she said yesterday. “That for me means it's appropriate to start discussing dialling back the level of accommodation that we're giving the economy on a regular basis, and the starting point for that is of course asset purchases.”

The Fed has said it would continue buying $120bn of agency mortgage-backed securities and Treasuries each month until it achieved “substantial further progress” on its goals of 2 per cent inflation on average and maximum employment.

Five more stories in the news

1. US calls on Opec to boost oil production The White House has urged Opec to increase oil output in an effort to curb high petrol prices that Biden administration officials say “risk harming the ongoing global recovery”. The intervention marked a shift from last year, when Donald Trump pressed Opec to raise prices to help US shale companies weather one of the worst market downturns in decades.

2. Afghanistan replaces army chief The Afghan government has replaced its army chief for the third time in just over a year, highlighting the disarray in the country as the Taliban sweeps aside the government's security forces. As the US prepares to withdraw the last of its troops, the Islamist rebels have captured nine provincial capitals and seized control of Kunduz airport.

3. China unveils five-year plan China has released a five-year plan to strengthen regulatory control over strategic sectors including technology and healthcare in Beijing's latest push to assert Communist party supremacy over the world's second-largest economy.

4. US inflation pace steadies The rapid pace of consumer price increases steadied at a 13-year high in July, with a 5.4 per cent rise from a year ago, as inflationary pressures persisted because of supply-chain constraints and soaring demand.

  • Opinion: At what point on the inflationary spectrum is economic officialdom playing with fire? It's the most important question in macro, writes Claire Jones.

5. Germany arrests Briton on suspicion of spying for Russia A British man working at the UK embassy in Berlin was arrested on suspicion of passing information to Russian intelligence services. The suspect, a local employee, rather than a diplomat, had been tracked for months before his arrest.

Coronavirus digest

  • The New York Stock Exchange will require evidence of a full Covid-19 vaccination for anyone wishing to access the trading floor.

  • The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has recommended Covid-19 vaccinations for pregnant women, saying that data indicated the Moderna and Pfizer shots did not increase the risk of a miscarriage.

  • The World Health Organization is to test three new drugs in hospitalised Covid-19 patients, as part of a global drive for coronavirus treatments among pre-existing medicines.

  • Europe's motley crew of Covid passport protesters have found unity in liberty.

  • New Zealand will gradually reopen its international border next year. Several crucial industries and the healthcare sector face severe skills shortages.

Zambia presidential election The southern African nation is braced for a tight race that will test the health of democracy and could further delay talks on a vital IMF bailout. President Edgar Lungu sent the army on to the streets ahead of today's poll.

Delta variant drives US employers to mandate vaccines Fear of a backlash from employees who distrust Covid-19 vaccines, or question an employer's right to impose them, had made most US companies reluctant. But in the past two weeks, vaccine mandates have gone from a rarity to a priority on California tech campuses and at the headquarters of Wall Street banks.

After Cuomo's downfall, New York reconsiders its politicians In the wake of the governor's resignation, some New Yorkers are now wondering whether a political culture dominated by hyper-aggressive men prone to scandal may be ready for something new.

Switzerland's ‘Silicon Valley of smell' The Covid-19 pandemic has changed how people want themselves, their clothes and their homes to smell. On the outskirts of Geneva is proof of how lucrative scent can be. The efforts of two companies that dominate the way the world smells are exacting, almost Willy Wonka-like, writes Sam Jones.
